div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definitely engaged as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marsailles, Gibraltar, Plymouth and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving in London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 p.m. on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fare is £22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles.
Passengers having paid full fare in one direction are allowed an abatement of 25 percent on returning within 12 months.
In addition to above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnightof 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or Marseilles.
TO THE EAST

The Mail Steamers leave Suez for Aden and Bombay every Wednesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcoutta, fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - CAIRO.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt - - - - - - - -SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE. In connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly 6 p.m., Wednesday for Port Sudan and Saukin direct returning from Suakin evry Wednesday at noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodbidah, Aden. Intermediate steamersdo not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

Highest class cuisine, electric light throughout, and lifts. English comforts. Rooms and apartments at prices to suit everyone. For further particulars apply to GENERAL MANAGER, Cairo.

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: The English Daily Newspaper, Established 1880
Editor and Manager - - R. SNELLING.
Price: ONE PIASTRE TARIFF.
WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 3, 1906.
MOSCOW.

Some one has said that there are only two cities in the world which tall at a glance their people’s history—Moscow and London. The one capital indicates the continuous and peaceful expansion of a people steadily growing into freedom and power, saved by its situation from foreign interference, and with communications open to all the world ; the other is a capital, which slowly straggled into existence as the only position of any strategical value in a country exposed to constant menace, and bearing the soars of many a bitter conflict. It is a city hallowed to the Russian mind as the centre of national resistance to their foes, sacrificed to Tartars, French, and Poles alike, hot rising again with renewed splendour, and dearer for all that it had antlered. Petersburg may be the seat of Government, and the means of communication with the West; but Moscow is the abiding home of Russian sentiment, the local centre round which patriotism gathers. How comes it then that this great city, the centre of the ideals of the most conservative and backward of European nations, has fallen into line with Warsaw, Batoum, Odessa, Riga, and all the other centres of revolutionary rage and now lies prone before the soldiery, who have only overcome the people after a slaughter to which no other European capital in modern history can show a precedent, for the horrors of the Commune were child's play compared to the havoc of carnage that this Christmastide has aeon in the city of the Kremlin 1

The best description of the state of the citylast week prior to the collapse of the rebellion ii contained in an article contributed to a London contemporary by Mr. Percival Gibbon, who has gone to Russia to examine the symptom, of the country. He remarks :

Wrong, grinding wrong, the effects of autocracy, which are the more murderous the deeper they barrow through the social layers of the nation, the hanger that was the portion of this group of millions, the pain that was the dole of that, the servility and dumbness that were the lot and duty of all, the strife of the instincts of manhood with the need to lira under the ferocious law and lack of law—thaw, and these alone, have made the revolution. Ah I yon may stay your Socialist with words, yon may drug your faddist with arguments, yon may hash your politician with the menace of bayonets; bat aching soul. Of men, sore with injustice, outraged and avid—neither Tsar nor satrap, nor battalions, nor logic, nor right, nor wrong, can avail to withhold them from the fixed goal. That is what rages in Russia today, and the passion of it, the packed force of stored wrath and enlightenment, have stormed Moscow as the Huns stormed the Urals. The tenseness of it is in the air; one breathes the spirit of revolution in the streets. The counsel of instructive years; the cautiousness of the proudest diplomacy, the deliberation of picked learning—these have been swamped, overridden, stamped under, as standing com goes down under a tempest of hail. Moscow the wise, the infinitely patient, the lordly in arts, the kingly in craft, is throbbing with the passion of a fishwife.

For generations she has been the stronghold of the traditions of autocracy, of that unbending conservatism which is yet the foundation of the spirit of Russia. She was the bride of the race; St. Petersburg, French and fins; dancing a Russian measure to a foreign fiddle, was no more than a mistress, a servant of acquired tastes and cultivated appetites. But Moscow stood for Russia; she bred the thought that moved the country, shrined the ideals which ail men accepted, and led the leisurely ordered advance of Russia towards the civilization her pundits prescribed for the people. Hers was the index to which men looked in doubt, and the change that has come over Moscow since the revolutionists became openly active will do more to upset the poise of Russian life than all the violences which daily perpetrate themselves throughout the empire.

For this reason, Moscow leads no more. It is in the whirlpool with the rest of the flotsam, circling as madly as any. Its society is honeycombed with associations, all eager to be potent, all squabbling over points of doctrine like Spanish monks. This ODB, with a famous scientist for its show member, desires a certain special ouvee of Republicanism; another strives alongside the Constitutionalists; a third squeals for the present Romanoff to be superseded by another. Among them the groups of real workers stand oat like men among pigmies, bat even these divide themselves among a dozen parties, and agree in nothing save that a change is wanted and must be brought about. The complications of interest go down even to the labourers in the market, who will combine for nothing bat stoning the police and marching in noisy procession at the tail of a red flag.

What is needed is a man; all agree on that point The time is ripe tor the appearance of the Overman, the great personality who shall give this movement a constructive aim to be the complement of its destructive tendencies and instincts. His absence is the one thing that tempts one to doubt the reality of the revolution; hitherto there has never been a great demand for a leader bat a man has been forthcoming, whether a Napoleon or only a Wat Tyler. Today one has bat to shout in the streets of Moscow and one’s followers will come tanning, and yet the man who must be ere Russia can realize her destiny has not transpired. What a glory lies to his hand when he breaks from the crowd to take! What a halo is wreathed for his name when he lets the world hear it! And how he will dragoon Moscow when he comes! How he will handle her till she speaks in a hash and develops hands to what her tongue has hardly dared to name! He will be hard on Moscow.

Since those lines were written the Overman has appeared in the shape of shot and shell and 20,000 corpses block the streets of the old Capital, which has exhibited a frenzy of revolution unparalleled even by Odessa or Cronstadt.

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL.
div.p: Boulac Institute.
A ball will be given at the Boulac Institute on Thursday, 18th inst.
The Brindisi Mail.
The mail will be distributed at the G.P.O., Alexandria, at 9.3** p.m. to day.
Rudolph Home.
Mrs. von T-chudi ha« contributed £1 to the funds of the Home, and Mr. G. B. Alderson has sent three ’Xmas puddings.
Cairo's Eastern Suburbs.
The Company is negotiating with the Ministry of Public Work* for gas and electric light installations at Zeitoun and Matarieb.
A Nilotic Mongoose.
Mr. 1. I. Harrison has presented a white-tailed mongoose from the Upper Nile to the Zoological Society of London.
Suez Municipal Elections,
The elections for 1906-1907 have been held at Suez. Abdul Rahman Bey Kami has been appointed chairman.
Accession Day,
The fete to celebrate the anniversary of the accession of the Khedive will be held in Cairo on the 8th inst. at 7 p.m. in the Esbekieh Gardens.
Mehkemeh for Sinai
An increase of L.E. 708 in the budget for the Mehkemehs for this year include the cost of the creation of a Court for the Peninsula of Sinai.
The Hedjaz Railway.

Toe Ottoman War Office has decided to employ 7,000 men of the Seventh Army Corps to finish the earthworks on the Hedjaz line up to Zat el-Hagg. The work will be finished before the pilgrims come back.
Well-deserved Promotion.
Saghcolaghassi Jarvis, Inspector of Police at Cairo, to whose untiring efforts the excellent state of Cairo's street traffic is in great measure due, has been promoted to the rank of Bimbashi.
Partnership.

M. H. Finck, proprietor of Diemer’s Bookstall, Cairo, has taken M. Eduard Baylaender into partnership, and the business will henceforward be conducted under the style of F. Diemer, Succ. Finck & Baylaender.
Disappeared.

Three European boys of Alexandria, of the names of Boriglioni, Lombardo, and Mieli respectively, have disappeared since early yesterday morning, and all efforts to trace their whereabouts have so far proved unavailing.
Appendicitis in Egypt.

An American contemporary announces that in over 2,000 major snrgical operations in Egypt upon natives only three cases of appendicitis were met with. This it attributed to vegetarian diet, light clothing, and moderate living.
Cinema Parisien.

The Cinema Parisien is the latest attraction at Alexandria and is drawing crowds to the El Dorado, which adjoins the Alhambra. The Cinema Parisien is an improved type of cinematograph, and the pictures which are thrown on the screen nightly are well worth seeing.
Military Service.

A circular has been issued by the Ministry of the Interior ordering the authorities of the gouvernorats and moodiriehs throughout Egypt to be on the look-out for and arrest conscripts who attempt to escape abroad to avoid military service.
From 1878 to 1906.

Constantly increasing success is the indie putable proof of the excellence of the teaching in the Berlitz School of Languages. The fir-t school was founded in 187**, and in 190$ three hundred of them, all flourishing, spread French, English, German, Italian, Greek, Arabic, Russian Japanese, etc., all over the world. 26, Roe de i'Eglise Copte, Alexandria; 1, Sharia Kamol, Cairo. [Advt]
Professor Petrie's Lectures*

The proceeds of Professor Petrie’s forthcoming lectures OP Egyptological subjects will be divided into equal shares; one for the Anglo American Hospital, one to be handed to the Very Reverend Dean Butcher for his distribution. Mr. Farnall has undertaken all the business arrangements connected with the lectures. We believe the first will be given towards the end of February.
Fatal Quarry Explosion.

A terrible accident took place in the neighbourhood of the Alexandria slaughter houses yesterday. Three natives were at work in a quarry and had laid a mine in order to extract a large quantity of fete DO. Before they bad got clear away after lighting the fuse the charge exploded. Two of the natives wen blown to pieces while the third was serious)} injured in the bead.
Children’s Matinee.

A children's manitee will be given on Sunday next by the opera company at the Zizinia Theatre, in aid of the Conservatoire of Music. The programme comprises the second act of Donizetti's Don Pasquale, with Sig. Fernando Gullet; Giaioli and Signs. Zcppilli, and Pierrot Soldat, a grand ballet pantomine by Maestro Loughi. The performance will conclude with the drawing of a monster "tombola” by Sig Fernando Gianoli.

div.head: COLD IN SYRIA.
div.p: HARD FROSTS AND SNOW.
SEVERAL DEATHS FROM EXPOSURE.

Syria has been experiencing the recent cold snap. Hard frosts and bitter winds are reported from Beyrout, and the Lebanon pastes are reported to have been absolutely blocked. All railway communication between Beyrout and Damascus was blocked for days on the plateau between Ain Sofar and Khan Murad, and several persons who were attempting to make their way over the Z-*bleb pass in the teeth of the storm died of cold and were found lying in the drifts.
It is paid that vast quantities of olive and mulberry trees have been uprooted and a goods train between Beyrout and Damascous was buried for some time in a snow drift.

div.head: THE BEDOUINS ARMING.
div.p: For some days past a great number of Bedouins have arrived at Alexandria from various districts, bat chiefly from Mariout and Siouf, and have been purchasing quantities of arms and ammunition. This morning the gunsmiths’ shops were filled with Bedouin purchasers of firearms.

One of our representatives asked a detective of the Alexandria City Police, who was watching these proceedings by one of the gunsmith’s establishments, what was the reason for these purchases. The detective replied that it was inexplicable as yet but that he intended notifying the authorities at the Alexandria Gouvernorat of the fact.
It was noted by our reporter that the Bedouins on leaving the shop carefully concealed their newly purchased arms within the spacious folds of their robes.

div.head: IMPORTATION OF CATTLE.
div.p: Following on the measures decided on & its meeting of the 7th November last in regard to cattle imported from abroad, the Quarantine Board, at its meeting yesterday, decided as follows :

1. Bovidea coming from countries free of disease, carried on the same boats with bovidae from forbidden countries, cannot be landed except at Alexandria and Port Said, so as to be slaughtered in quarantine at the port of destination.
2. Sheep arriving on the same steamers as cattle coming from infected countries, or which may have been kept in the same parks as these cattle, will also be slaughtered in quarantine.

div.head: THE MENA HOUSE CASE.
div.p: Yesterday the Ministre Public gave his conclusions on the preemption case brought by Dr. Rifky Pasha and his wife, the Princess, against Nungovich Bey in regard to the Mena House Hotel. The conclusions were in favor of the claimants for preemption.

div.head: THE SUCRERIES.
div.p: The judgment of the Cairo Commercial Tribunal will be given on Saturday next. Yesterday the experts, Sir William Willcocks. Fourneron Boy, and Professor Sampaolo, were convoked by Judge Tuck, who required certain information bearing on the case.

div.head: "ANTAR.”
div.p: H.H. the Khedive, after seeing Antar performed at the Khedivial Opera House, summoned M Chekri Ganem, the able author of Antar, to his box, to compliment him on the successful "first night” of his tragedy.
M. Camille Saint Saeus watched Antar from the Khedivial box. The veteran musician is staying for a month in Cairo.

div.head: ARMY INSPECTION.
div.p: Brig. General Bollock. C.B., commanding the Army of Occupation, made his annual inspection of the R.A.M C. to-day at the Military Hospital, Citadel, Cairo. He will inspect the 2nd Company, Royal Engineers, on the 5th inst., the 71st Company, Army Service Corps, on the 9th inst, and the 7th Company, Army Ordinance Corps on the 12th inst Brig.-General Bollock visited the Cairo military prison this morning.

div.head: A CASE FOR THE S. P. C. A.
div.p: A correspondent writes: - As I was walking along the northern side of Caesar’s Camp station yesterday afternoon with a friend I -aw an Arab mule driver ill-treating his mole in a most brutal manner. The cart was half leaded with sand and ODB of the wheels had sunk in the sand, the driver was standing by simply lending no help whatever to extricate it, only beating the poor animal with a stick and his reins about the head in a most on merciful manner ; directly I remonstrated with him he put his shoulder to the wheel and easily extricated it. I spoke to a lady who lived close by and she told me this was an every-day occurrence with various drivers at this spot, unfortunately she had not seen this particular case. I think the driver in question should be severely dealt with, his number is 2931.

div.head: TO-DAY’S TELEGRAMS.
div.p: THE GENERAL ELECTION.
DATES OF POLLING.
LIBERAL CHANCE OF SUCCESS.
(Gazette’s Special Service.)
London, Tuesday, Dec. 2.
The polling dates have been fixed as f ollows: London, 13th, 15th, and 16th inst; the country, from the 16th to the 25th inst.
LONDON, January 2.
The “Times” calculates that the Liberals must gain 76 seats in order to defeat the Unionists unaided, or 117 seats to confront a possible Unionist and Nationalist combination.
No fewer than 133 members of the House of Commons are not seeking re-election. ( Router)

div.head: CHINESE LABOUR QUESTION.
div.p: SPEECH BY MR. BALFOUR.
LONDON, January 2.

Speaking at Leamington, Mr.Balfour lengthily and passionately defended the employment of Chinese labour in the Transvaal. He declared that the Liberal leaders have done a gross injury to the morals of the country by spreading atrocious falsehoods and raising the electioneering cry of anti slavery, while in reality they have not the least intention to expel the coolies. (Router)

div.head: RUSSIAN REVOLUTION.
div.p: REPRESSIVE MEASURES.
ST. PETERSBURG, January 2.

General Sollohub, the new Governor-General of the Baltic provinces, has reached Riga with a strong force, and issued a conciliatory proclamation. Later on, three hundred workmen a apprised a detachment of dragoons, killing 11 and wounding 14. Eight workmen were killed. .General Sollohub reports initial movements of three forces under Generals Bendt, Meynhardt, arid Orloff. These forces are repairing the railways as they proceed. (Reuter)
ST. PETERSBURG, January 2.
The Government, being sure of the absolute fidelity of the troops, as proved by the latest events, has decided to exert its utmost to repress the revolutionary outbreaks. (Havas.)

div.head: JEWISH COLONY IN E. AFRICA.
div.p: PROMISE OF GOVERNMENT SUPPORT.
LONDON, January 2.

Mr. Churchill, in a letter to Mr. l. Zangwill, says that while the Earl of Elgin is bound to recognise the serious difficulties in the way of this foundation of a Jewish colony in East Africa, he will approach the subject with profound sympathy. Mr. Churchill feels that Mr. Zangwill’s noble vision of a settled home for Jews, under a flag of tolerance and freedom, should not be allowed to fade away, arid he will do his utmost for the furtherance of the scheme. (Rueter)

div.head: THE ALIENS CASE.
div.p: LONDON, January 2.
Fifteen of the immigrants rejected at Grimsby were subsequently admitted on the ground that they were political refugees. The others must return to Hamburg. (Reuter)

div.head: THROUGH SUEZ CANAL.
div.p: A REMARKABLE VOYAGE.
Washington.

J. D. Wood, a tug master of Norfolk, has just signed a contract with the navy department to go out to Manila on the D. D. Dewery, on one of the most1 remarkable cruises of modern times. The D. D Diwery means the big steel floating dry dock now at Solomon’s island in Chesapeake bay, which is destined to dock the largest ships of the American naval force in the far past if this great structure can ever be successfully piloted through four seas, the 14,000 miles lying between Chesapeake bay and Manila bay.

Mr. Wood is to live aboard the dock during the voyage. Ha anticipates one of the most pleasant experiences of his life. He will receive $250 compensation per month. His vessel will be so stable in the heaviest weather that it might be possible to play billiards aboard, according to some officers, and he will have plenty of good company and solid comforts. There is a permanent crew of eight machinists, engineers, sailors and electricians and firemen and those people are to remain attached to the dock at Manila. On the voyage across they will be reinforced by twenty-two sailors.

The sleeping accommodation on the dock are as good as the best on a man of war and there is an abundance of room. Receiving the best of merchant sailor pay, the crew will be abundantly fed, as the ration allowance for the cruise is placed at 60 cents each daily instead of the usual rate of 30 cents. There will be small boats and wireless telegraph installation. The navy department is still looking for three operators for this service, offering to pay the men $60 per month and allowances and to send them back from Manila.

This comparatively large crew is needed for the purpose of handling the towing lines and operating the pumps and electrical contrivances that keep the deck dry. They cannot steer the great hulk, for no constructor has bean able to devise a rudder big enough to shape a course for the dock which could be safely attached and operated. So the dock is to be held on its course solely by the towing power of the three great colliers, Glacier, Caesar and Brutus, the whole under command of Captain Fullam, United States navy. Each of the colliers will have its own wireless plant so that they may freely communicate with the dock and with each other. The towing line will be one and a half miles long, a length regarded as necessary to guard against sharp strains in a heavy sea and even with this great towing line bits with pneumatic cushions have been placed on the colliers to reduce the chance of breaking the cables, the largest steel ropes in the world.

Estimates vary as to the length of time that will be consumed in the voyage, but some of the most competent naval officers believe that the Dewey can be towed at the rate of about one hundred miles a day, and allow about three or four months for the trip via the Suez canal.

div.head: The Wardan Estate Company.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA HARBOUR.
div.p: THE NEW EXTENSION.

Owing to the extraordinary development of the port of Alexandria of recent years, much trouble has been caused by the congested state of the harbour. The Government last year made a grant of L.E 206,000 to enable further improvements to be carried out, and since thou a farther big grant has been made for the same purpose. The money is now being expended on gigantic works, which will enormously increase the accommodation of the port. In fact, the coast in the immediate western neighbourhood of the port, from Gabbari to Mex, is now being transformed and in a short space of time it will be the centre of a new port, which will be the scene of as much activity, and the centre of as busy a population, as is the present harbour. The following is a sketch of the chief works now in the course of construction.

div.head: THE COAL QUAY.
div.p: The coal quay was only 35 metres broad four years ago and since then has been increased to 90 metres. A still farther extension re obligatory and it is in course of being widened to 150 metres. A new arm is being added to the end of the coal quay in a southwesterly direction, which will accommodate three berths. Two berths will be completed on the main coal quay extension within one month and in three months there will be two other berths finished and ready on the new arm of the quay. As the works proceed more and more new berths will be opened as they are needed. A credit of L E 88.000 was opened for this quay tut this sum Ins almost all been spent as the works for which it was allotted have nearly been finished. Fresh credits will be voted as the need arises.

M. Malavel, the chief engineer to the Porte and Lighthouses Administration, to whom this work is entrusted, has invented an excellent system for embankments, which is being followed in these constructions.

In order to obtain a solid foundation it is necessary to clear off the mud by throwing down enormous quantities of sand, which, presses on the mud and by mere force of its weight drives the mud away. A dredger is then employed in order to dig out a site for the walls, the foundation of which are nine metres in depth. Then artificial blocks, nine cubic metres square, quarried at Mex, are put down.
This method has up to date given excellent results and M. Malavel is to be congratulated on having solved a difficult problem in the, laying of these foundations.

The embankments constricted up to now have a superficies of 25,000 square metres, which, taking into consideration the average depth of from 19 to 20 metres, makes 500,000 cubic metres of earth removed from the land . between Wardian and Gabbari.

The south end of the coal quay is being enlarged 90 metres in order to admit of sufficient space for coal depots at d railway lines from Gabbari station. A credit of L.E. 10,000 has been accorded for this special work.

At the end of the coal quay, where the Gabbari quay begins, a store of 3,600 square metres in extent is being erected for the storage of oil and fat imports, etc. The building is of masonry with a terrace of beton arme and is supported by a number of columns, also in beton arme. At the end of the store two sheds are being built where lime and cement will be stored.

By the semaphore by the side of the, new dock it is intended to construct a quay for embarking and disembarking passengers. In the rear of the semaphore is the quarry whence the material for the erection of the: coal quay was extracted. On the site of this exhausted quarry, for the earth there has now been levelled, the yards for the artificial blocks for the timber quays will be situated. Later on these enormous areas will be occupied by the depots of the timber merchants.

The uplands, known by the name of Om el-Koubbebeh, will be levelled and thrown into the sea in order to be utilised for the timber- quays. Some blocks have already been placed in position here. These timber quays will consist of three moles, 120 metres in length and 100 metres in width. Beyond these moles there will be a flat surface, shoot 80 metres broad, where the blocks of timber will be sorted and where there will also be the roads and railway lines. Behind this up to the Mex high road there is to be a large piece of land for the depots of the timber merchants.

The above are only some of the items in the great programme now being undertaken by the Egyptian Government in order to increase the accommodation of the port of Alexandria. In our next article we will review the remainder of the works. In the meantime we advise our readers to repair themselves to the scene of enormous activity, which is destined to entirely transform the line of coast that stretches from the Gabbari end of the port if Alexandria westwards to Mex.

div.head: GREECE OF TO DAY.
div.p: AN INTERESTING BOOK.

We congratulate Mr. Miller on having produced an excellent little book on modern Greece. It is instructive and yet amusing, detailed yet resourceful, and full of picturesque touches and poetic flashes which make it extremely pleasant reading. The author is by no means a mere casual spectator. He has studied many of her racial, political, and social problems with great care, and on many of them he expresses very sound opinions. To begin with he maintains that the theory that the old Hellenic blood and race are extinct is fallacious and in this contention he will, we believe, be supported by the most intelligent modern scholars. As Professor Mahaffy has often pointed oat, the Greeks of modern times have many of the qualities of the ancient Hellenes. We have got to believe that every Greek of the days of Pericles was a genius, but the belief is as false as one which should hold that all the contemporaries of Shakespeare were men of his standard. The average Athenian of Aristophanes’ day was probably, says Mr. Miller, not very different from the present frequenters of the cafes in Constitution-square at Athens. The most marked qualities which ho notices amongst the Greeks of to-day are curiosity, hospitality, and a general democratic tendency. No sooner do you arrive at an inu than the girls of the house come in and ransack your luggage from sheer curiosity. Yet if you are on a little Greek steamer plying amongst the islands and food is not plentiful, the Greek officers will go without their dinner so that you may have yours in plenty. In politics there is, of coarse, great corruption, yet many rich Greeks have grown poor in office. One head of expense arises from the duty of standing godfather to the children of your constituents, and there is a popular statesman in Athens to-day who is said to have a thousand godchildren in Attica. The desire for change is, however, now, as in the days of St. Paul, ineradicable in the Greek. There have been fifty-four Ministries in the last forty-two years and five in the last twelvemonth. No great questions divide parties, and the crises are simply disputes between rival leaders each with a band of followers whom he must appease with the spoils of office. The “spoils system” is in full swing in Greece, and with the very worst results.

The modern Greeks have done nothing in literature, and there is but a small market for books. Newspapers are read with the utmost avidity, and Athens boasts almost as many daily papers as London. Jules Verne and Marie Corelli are read in translations, and there is a small number of people who study Byron, Macaulay, end Shakespeare, but moat of the Greeks who read English confine themselves to the daily and weekly papers which come from England. Education is bad, chiefly because schoolmasters go in and out with the Government, and this defect may be the cause of the low standard of literary and academic taste. In this connection we may notice that England still lags behind America-, France, and Germany in her efforts for Greek archaeology. Our British School is starved, and the attempts to raise funds for it in England are not successful. This is a reproach to England which, we hope, will soon be wiped out. Mr. Miller talks pleasantly of society both in the capital and the country, and notices, as all travellers in Greece do, that Turkish customs have not yet died out. The Greek ladies—except the cosmopolitans, who imitate Paris customs—live still in semi-seclusion, some indeed in complete privacy. Hence it comes that the Greek seldom entertains in his own house; and yon may knew a man for months in Athens without even finding out whether he is married or not. As to country life, Mr. Miller rightly deplores the tendency of the modern Greek to desert his fields and hills for the towns. This tendency is very strong in Greece to-day, and is undoubtedly causing physical deterioration. He gives a vivid account of the promontory of Maud, the central prong of the Peloponnesus. Here the descendants of the ancient Spartans still subsist upon their rocky hills — so rocky that it is said there that when God was creating the world the bag containing the stones burst over Mane. Here survive the fierce traditions of the vendetta, the highest code of respect for women, the strictest rule, of unbounded and unquestioning hospitality. Here, too, are rival highland clans, the Campbells and the Camerons of the Peloponnesus, though to-day they fight their battles, rather over municipal elections than over the, ownership of fields or cattle. The account, of this place is most interesting, and reminds one of Lord Carnarvon's travels at the commencement of the Victorian Era. There is, much more on Church, and education, and so forth to attract the reader, but we will lease him to enjoy the book for himself. It has only one possible disadvantage, it will make him long to go to Greece, or—if he has been there before—to go again.

div.head: ZIZINIA THEATRE.
div.p: “TANNHAUSER.”

The present opera company should by this time have accustomed us to look for success in most of their undertakings; yet we confess the inclusion of Tannhauser in the repertoire was a little shaking to our confidence. Nor, we regret to say, were our fears entirely groundless. Yesterday’s performance, though it contained several good features, showed much want of finish and comprehension. The wide difference separating the Italian rendering of Wagner from the German is not merely confined to the change of language nor even to the national characteristics attaching thereto, but lies largely in the fact that the Italians do not partake of that semi-religious “schwarmerei” so faithfully observed in German representations. The audience, too, does not come so muoh with the idea of being impressed and uplifted as with being entertained, or, at beat, diverted. Nevertheless, whether sung in' Italian or German, so profound, so speaking, so true to natural instincts is the music, that let it but be truly interpreted and none can fail to be deeply moved by it. While a previous knowledge of Tannhauser is practically a necessity if its fall beauties are to be followed, yet a slight knowledge of the plot is enough to enable one, through the medium of the wonderfully inspired motifs, to hear, as it were, the very thoughts and impulses of each and every character. We will not deny that last night’s performance to some extent conveyed to us this impression. Maestro Zuccani deserves credit for the manner in which he entered on his strenuous task. He evidently took great pains to work op the production, but there is unquestionably room for much farther improvement, which, we make no doubt, will be instilled into future representations here. One felt it had been embarked upon too light- heartedly and that it was not fully realised that it is one thing to frolic through light Italian opera and another to rise to so big a venture as Tannhauser.

The house had evidently assembled in high good humour and vociferously applauded the overture, which had to be encored and. was far better played the second time than the first. The orchestra also did surprisingly well with the Venusberg music, and Signa. Zappilli’s Venus was as charming in execution as in appearance. Sig. Longobardi, as Tannhauser was not at his best, being prevented by a cold from giving to his part all the force which it exacted. He also requires, as we have remarked before, to throw himself with more dash and vigour into his idles. He failed last night to impress us as a man swayed this way and that by tumultuous emotions. In the second scene of this act, the orchestra continued good but was sadly hampered by an unexpressive rendering of the peasant’s song, usually so sweetly fresh. The first appearance of the pilgrims was fairly good, the crescendo and diminuendo being well observed, and the entry of the knights of the Wartburg led the act to a successful finale.

Act II. was well interpreted from first to last. To begin with, the Elisabeth of Signa. Giannina Russ was a remarkably fine, display of talent. She mastered her score with apparent ease and fulfilled every requirement. Sig. Nicolay as the Landgrave was properly dignified in his singing and acquitted himself well. At Sig. Amato’s Wolfram we were prepared to wax very enthusiastic; he certainly worked his hardest in this act to fill his part with exactness and sympathy, and need his voice, which is of a very pleasing timbre, to its best effect. But for some unaccountable reason be disappointed us in Act III and might have done more justice to the “Evening Star” romance. The famous march was exceedingly well given by all exponents and the orchestra maintained their standard throughout Act II and did what they could in the following one, which was unluckily a very tame affair. In fact Signa. Russ’s fine singing of Elisabeth’s prayer and the efforts of the orchestra saved the act from comparative failure. Let us draw the curtain of charitable silence on the lamentable collapse of the chorus and finale. It was a pity to have to wait until nearly 1.30 a.m. to witness such a debacle. Once again we raise our voices at the terribly long waits, and if really nothing can be done to remedy this evil, the play should at least commence at an earlier hour.

div.head: *AN AMERICAN IN EGYPT.
div.p: Some interesting observations in Egypt are contained in Egypt, Burma and Malaysia by Mr. William Eleroy Curtis, the well-known American newspaper correspondent. Simplicity, rapidity, vividness, and a certain positiveness mark his writings, and have won for him a wide circle of daily readers. He has unusual faculties for observing the surface life of foreign lands, and the ability to marshal his data in good order. His recent look entitled respectively "Egypt, Burma, and Malaysia” is a model of a reporter’s note book in foreign lands. The author conducts us over the usual routes and amid often described scenes. Port Said, Alexandria, Cairo, 'ever new and novel to the oldest traveller,’ the Pyramids, the Sphinx, and the Nile, are of course the main points of interest in Egypt. To add anything new to these old familiars would be impossible; but Mr. Curtis’s view point is at times refreshing. It is out of the common run of description to read that the famous ideal of mystery in stone has 'no more expression than there would be in any sandstone image that has been hit square on the nose by a three hundred pound shot fired from a French cannon and had its features scattered over a square mile of desert.’
EGYPT, BURMA, AND MALAYSIA. By William Eleroy Curtis. Illustrated, Chicago: Fleming H. Revell Company.

div.p: COUR D’APPEL MIXTE.
L’A K FAI RE DAVEY-POUTREL

L’Hon. Arthur Davey, admiuistrateur-délé gué de la Société Générale dea Sucreries et Raffit.erie d’Egypte poursuit eu diffamation M. Pontrel. On ae rappelle que celui-ci avait attaqué Davey pour un motif analogue : reuvoi injustifié et atteinte b sou houueur. Noos avons à l’époque reproduit le jugement du tri bunal mixte du Caire qui a débouté Poutrsl de son action, mais n’a pas davantage reconnu la demande reoonventionnelle de Davey.

Ce dernier a fait appel du jugement du tri bunal du Caire : l’affaire est venue ce matin devant la Cour d’Appel mixte ; mais, en dépit de l'insistance de Me Carton de Wiart pour plaider tout de suite, l’avocat de Poutre! obtenu le renvoi dea plaidoiries à une date ultérieure.

div.head: L’AFFAIRE DO PRINCE HALIM
div.p: Le procès du prince Halim contre Hosn Gull et oonsorts a été également renvoyé à plus tard pour les plaidoieriea. Les parties en cause sont, en effet, en voie d’arrangement et si l'accord aboutit, comme tout donne lieu de le croire, l’affaire sera rayée du rôle.

div.head: AFFAIRE D’ACCIDENT
div.p: Il s’agit d’un aocident survenu en ÿin 1903 b Hélouan : Ibrahim bey Zobeir, qui montait un obeval, s'étant abattu sur la dame Barnob celle-oi eut une jambe fraotorée.

Le Tribunal du Caire, appelé b statuer sur l’affaire, retint la responsabilité du père Zobeir Pacha, paroe que le cheval était sa propriété ei que son fils agissait en cette oocasion oomme son préposé ; il condamna dono Zobeir Pacba Rahmet b payer b la dame Barnch LE. > ,600 de dommages-intérêts.
La Coor, devant laquelle le différend a été porté, vient de réformer ce jugement et de débouter la dame Barnch de sa demande, en la condamnant aux dépens de première instance et d’appel.

La Cour estime, en effet, que laresponsabilité du propriétaire de l'animal ne peut exister que si l’animal de son propre mouvement a occasionné l’acoident, ce qui ne peut être le cas, lorsqu’il est monté par un homme. De plus Zcbair Pacha oonteste qu’il soit le propriétaire du cheval, et nie avoir donné auoun ordre b ein fils de le m inter. Il soutient eu outre que son fils était mijaur et marié au moment de l'accident et s’offre b le prouver.

div.head: DELEGATION MUNICIPALE
div.p: ( Communication Officielle)
La Délégation Municipale s’est réunie le 2 janvier 1906 sous la présidenoe de Mr. Amb. A. Ralli b 4 h. p.m.
Présents : MM. C. Banachi, P. Fenderl, Mansour Bey Youssef, G. Zervudachi, mena bres, W. P. Chataway. administrateur, I. Sedky Bey, secrétaire.
La Délégation autorise une dépense de LE. 80 pour l’achat de 3 appareils portatifs des tuyaux d’arrosage des rues.
Elle demandera b la Commission un orédit de LB. 60 pour la consolidation du sous-sol de la route de Chatby, préalablement b son empierrement
Elle désigne un Comité composé de MM. Abani Bey, Stross et Fenderl, pour proposer de conoert aveo le Président et l’Administrateur, un programme des routes b paver et b macadamiser en 1906.
Elle décide l'éolairage des ponts du Mah- moodieh au moyen de la lampe b pétrole “ Lux ’’ dont le ooût est de beaucoup moins élevé que celui du système proposé par 1^ Compagnie du Gaz.
Elle proposera b la Commission la nomination du Comité spécial b adjoindre b la Dé'é- gatîon pour la nomination de l’ingénieur électricien dont le poste, prévu au budget sera mis au oonconra.

La Délégation s'oooupe de la question de la oonstruotion d’un nouveau théâtre b Alexandrie. Elle est en principe favorable au projet tendant b venir en aide b l’entreprise qni se chargerait de la construction de oet édifice sur des plans approuvés par la Municipalité.
Le concours de la Municipalité consisterait en une concession gratuite de terrain et une subvention annuelle pour une durée déterminée b la fin de laquelle le théâtre serait propriété municipale.
Un échange d'idées a lieu an sujet des moyens financiers b employer dans ce but, b la sui'e duquel le service est chargé de présenter un rapport.
En ce qui concerne l'emplacement, la Délégation sa réserve de le proposer ultérieurement, lorsque la Commission aura bien voulu adopter les principes exposés ci dessus.
La séance est levée a 6 h. 1/2 p.m.

div.p: Il résulte du bilan publié par la sooiété que l’ensemble des réserves s’élève b LH 62,436.388 et celui des amortissements b L.K. 52,869.619 ; ce qui fait un total de LE 115,296 007 eutre amortissements effectués et réserves constituées au 31 Août 1905.
Le passif, actions diverses et obligations, est de LE. 529,418.500.

L'actif composé des usines, titres Unifiée et Port Said Sait Association, Stock marchand! ses, dépôts en caisse et chez les banques, porte feuille commercial, atteint LB 588,166.423 Après déduotion de L E. 25,646.145 pour o«é anciers divers et de LE. 6,711 moyennant le. quelles la prévision de L S.-22,904.7-0 tenue eu réserve pour Bel au gouvernement se trou vera réglée d'après le nouvel accord, il res'c net L R 555,808.278.
Il faut noter que dans est état les deux cou oessions de la soude (qui est pour 50 ans) et d a sel sont calculés pour zéro.

A noter également que le stook permanent de sel appartenant b l’Etat qui avait été cédé b la Société pour une somme de L.E. 22,904.700 était calculé sur la base de LE. 5 par tonn», o’est-b dire aveo une redevance de 340 P.T. par tonne. Cette redevance disparaissant avec le retrait du monopole, il ne reste plus que le prix effeotif du sel.

Sous le régime du monopole le sel était vendu P.T. 500, soit, en déduisant la redevance de P.T 340, P.T. 160 net. Aveo la nouvelle concession le sel sera vendu P.T. 184 net de tous frais de douane. La sooiété bénéficie dono de la différence qui existe entre P.T. 184 et 160, soit de 16 P.T. par tonne.

On voit par oes données, abstraction faite du coupon de 4 % qui a été décidé et qui re piéseute une somme ds LE 18,000, que l’abolition du monopole est loin de porter atteinte b la prospérité de l’Egyptian Sait and Soda.

div.head: FINANCIAL ADVISER'S NOTE.
div.p: To the Editor of the Egyptian Gazette.

Sir,—A perusal of the portion of the Financial Adviser’s Note on the Budget published in your issue of the 26th inst. by any one unacquainted with Egypt must leave the impression that the much vaunted prosperity of the country has been greatly exaggerated and that the country is on the brink of a financial catastrophe owing to over-speculation.

It is a matter for deep regret that a high Government official should step in and make authoritative statements which, after all, can only be an expression of personal opinion, and however eminent a man may be, he is but human and subject to error.

The people who will read the Financial Adviser's Note are practically confined to Egypt and the United Kingdom. In Egypt, owing to personal knowledge of the situation, the effect will not be serious, but in England there is no doubt very considerable importance will be given to the views expressed and it will certainly have the effect of further retarding the flow of English capital into Egypt If the Financial Adviser is correct in his views be doubtless will be rendering a considerable service to the British public by preventing them from investing money in a country verging on bankruptcy, but if on the other hand he is making a mistake the British public who have expended their blood and treasure so freely to reclaim Egypt from the financial ruin and anarchy existing in 1882 will be the only European nation that will not profit by the prosperity of the country. European capital, with the exception of British, is flowing freely into Egypt, and has been doing so for several years past, it will continue to do so in spite of the Financial Adviser’s “note of warning." This, however, is not the point, the question we have to deal with is whether the Financial Adviser is correct in the opinions he so ably expresses in the Budget Note under review.

No one for a moment doubts that in giving expression to his views Sir Vincent Corbett is actuated by motives of highest principle and a sincere desire to benefit the public in general, bat let us analyze facts. His Budget, in spite of his efforts to minimise the eloquence of figures, speaks volumes of the growing prosperity of Egypt, for notwithstanding a low Nile flood in 1901, and the remission of taxation during the three preceding years of about half a million pounds, the revenue of the year now ending exceeds that of the previous year by about one million pounds, or 7 1/2 %. Sir Vincent Corbett next proceeds to ascribe the increase in the price of necessaries of life in Egypt to the appreciation in value of land and the sudden acquisition of unexpected wealth by large sections of the community; he gives as an illustration a list of certain commodities such as wheat, beans, lentils, etc., quoting the prices the Government paid in 1904 and-1905 for there articles.

No clearer proof, than this portion of his note, can be produced to show how an able man can go astray when venturing to express an opinion on subjects with which he is not fully acquainted. Sir Vincent Corbett is not a commercial man, otherwise he would not attribute to the increased wealth of the community the rise in the price of wheat from P.T. 108 per ardeb in 1904 to P.T. 128 in 1905 or beans from P.T. 6Q to P.T. 116 and so on through the list of articles which he quotes. The price of wheat in Egypt, like that of every other country, is subject to the law of supply and demand. Egypt does not produce enough wheat fur its own consumption, consequently large quantities of flour are imported. It is the first cost of this flour plus freight, Customs duty, merchants’ profit and all other expenses that regulates the price of wheat in Egypt, no amount of "acquisition of unexpected wealth" would put up the price one piastre per ardeb if a corresponding increase in the price of flour did not take place in the market from which Egypt draws her supplies. To argue the contrary would be to imply that importers of flour into Egypt during 1905, taking the Financial Adviser’s figures, were clearing a profit 0f 25% on the value of every sack of flour they imported plus the profit they were making in 1904. The same arguments applies to each of the other articles quoted in a greater or less degree. In saying this it is not for a moment contesting the fact that the more prosperous a community may be the more if the necessaries as well as luxuries of life it will consume per head of population, but it is maintained that the price of commoditie- which are staple articles of commerce are unaffected by the prosperity of the country in which they are sold, their price being regulated by the world’s supply of the same. In analyzing the imports and exports the Financial Adviser makes the following remarks, i. e, " The fact that during the past two years the imports of merchandise and specie taken together have greatly outbalanced the exports notwithstanding the constant heavy charge for the service of the foreign debt constitutes a phenomenon which calls for reflection. A readjustment in the direction of normal equilibrium most come about sooner or latter and if we are paying for imports with capital provided by the foreign investor this operation, though by no means necessarily unsound at present cannot be indefinitely continued. ” This question of imports as compared with exports is one that has exercised the minds of experts in every country for many generations, and though figures can be made to prove anything one way or the other, the broad fact remains that many of the most prosperous countries in the world, including the United Kingdom, import goods of a much greater value than those they export, consequently the fact that the imports into Egypt are now exceeding the exports may be taken as a proof that the prosperity of the country has come to stay.

Under the heading of "Speculation in Egypt” the Financial Adviser sounds a note of warning which he admits, coming from one in his position, will carry more weight than if pronounced by an ordinary individual. He doubtless expresses his honest convictions, but it is a pity that he should have allowed himself to make such a sweeping pronouncement on a subject with which, to his honour be it said, he evidently is unacquainted. Sir Vincent Corbett is unquestionably confusing speculation with gambling ; where the latter begins, and where the former ends, no one has been able to define for the one runs so much into the other that it is impossible to separate them, and yet they are quite distinct. Speculation is the very breath in the nostrils of all commercial enterprise ; take away speculation and where would onr great engineers be who plan and carry out great financial enterprises? They may plan railways and bridges, steamboats and factories, but without the speculator behind them to supply the sinews of war in the shape of £ s. d. how many of such works would be carried out? And how far on the road of civilisation would the world have advanced? Unfortunately, where there is speculation there gambling will also come in, but it would he as wise to condemn the whole system of banking because cheques are often forged as to make a sweeping condemnation of speculation because men make use of it to gamble. Having said so much let us now see if gambling really exists in an excessive degree in Egypt.

The only serious gambling is that of the Cotton Bourse, bat it is nothing in proportion as compared with legitimate cotton speculation to what exists in the cotton markets of Liverpool and New-York. This gambling in "futures" has existed for many years, and though efforts have been made in many countries, no legislation that human ingenuity can devise has been able to stop it.

Turning to stocks and share, though people make and lose money in buying and selling there is nothing approaching the gambling that takes place in the stock and share markets of other co entries for the reason that there is no "term market” in Egypt ; here and there a broker may arrange with a client as a special agreement to carry for him a number of shares for the end of the month bat there is no regular "settling days” with fixed rates of “Contago" and all the machinery that has been specially devised to enable men with a limited command of ready cash to boy and sell thousands of shares, whereas in Egypt with the same means at their disposal they can only deal in hundreds. No one can bay more shares than he can carry for the simple reason that no Bank in Egypt will advance more than 70 to 80 % of the market value on dividend-paying shares and nothing on shares of companies that have not yet paid a dividend. This fact demonstrates the soundness of the financial position of Egypt, for it is no exaggeration to state that at least 80 % of the capital of all the better established Egyptian public companies, including the National and Agricultural Bank, is held by Egyptian shareholders, and practically the whole of the capital of all the new companies on which the hanks have made absolutely no advances has been found by Egypt.

The most important point, however, in Sir Vincent Corbett’s note of warning, and the one that will have the most repellent effect on he British capitalist, is his statement that values of land "have been forced up to levels which even prospective results can hardly prove to be remunerative,’’ Is this so? What is the value of land? Taking agricultural land first, the answer to the latter question that would probably be glibly given is that the maximum value of land is reached when it becomes a 5% investment. Agricultural land has not yet reached the 5% limit in Egypt except in rare cases, but even if it had what holds good in other countries do-a not necessarily apply to Egypt at present, nor will it for ma- y years to come, for the fellah, now that he has been emancipated from the money lender and tax collector, has a larger income than his frugal expenditure demands, for his savings he has absolutely only two investments, one to dig a hole in some secret corner of his house and bury his money, the other to purchase land ; the former of course brings him no return whatever, the latter may bring him in £3, £5, or even £10 per feddan per annum according to quality of soil, etc. He does not know nor does he pare anything about per cent. per annum, but what he knows and what he particularly cares about that the more feddans of land he owns the greater will be his importance in the eyes of his fellow-villagers and the greater the respect he will receive at their hands, consequently as the fellah’s prosperity increases the value of agricultural land will increase in the same proportion and this for several generations to come until the fellaheen of Egypt are sufficiently educated to seek other and more remunerative investments. To say that the value of agricultural land in Egypt has reached its maximum is to state that the prosperity of the fellaheen has also reached its maximum, whereas no one, not even the Financial Advisor, will dispute the fact that much as the fellah has so far prospered his prosperity of to-day is nothing to what, it will be to-morrow. Turning to building lands in the chief towns of Egypt, which have been subject to such enhancement of value of late, we have not only Sir Vincent Corbett but many others with him paying that speculation has forced up prices far above the r proper value. Is this so 1 The only way of testing this fact is to compare the value of building sites in Cairo and Alexandria with towns of similar size and importance in other countries ; if this is done it will astonish them to find that even at the present supposed inflated values the price of building sites both in Cairo and Alexandria are lower and in fact in many cases less than half what they are in similar situations in towns of lets importance. This may sound incredible but a little enquiry

can establish the point The faot is also easy of explanation. For many years ths attention of the moneyed olass in Egypt haa been concentrated on agricultural land over whioh large and tapid fortunes have been amassed, also the large number of old houses with hoge gardens and open spaces that have been available fur. building purposes have kept the supply of bnilding sites wall in exoesa of demand, hence the inorease in valne until quite recently was in no way oommensnrate with the increased prosperity of lha country. Daring the last year or two the Government having stopped the sale of all available agrionltnral lands, the attention of the pnblio has been diverted to bnilding sites and there has been a rash to secure the same. Naturally prices have run np bnt even now they are 1 iw compared with the rental valne of bo se property. In oonolosion it cannot be too strongly urged that olfioiala in a position to make "ex cathediA" statements cannot be too oareful to confine themselves to absolute indisputable faota, or there is no donbt that the constant sounding ot “notes of warning” by Lard Cromer in his annual reports, thongh actuated by the highest motives of .stateman- ship, has so far had the effeot of keeping mnoh English oapital ont of Bgypt, to the benefit of foreign oonntries, and now Sir Vinoent Corbet’a Budget Note will have the effeot of still farther repelling it. The faot of the matter is that onr administrators, unable to bring themselves to regard the extraordinarily su joes.-fnl results whioh their able and impartial administration has achieved, as permanent, are seeking for an explanation which they oan only find in the "Speonlation Bogey.”—I am, Sir, a sinoere admirer of the BRITISH ADMINISTRATION IN KQYPT.
Cairo, 30 Dec. 1905.
